Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2011 06:43PM bedo wrote: Inyoureyes.  Don't let the Category 4 throw you off.  Insurance is so awful about denying procedures that the doctor HAS to put down suspicious, even if he/she thinks it's benign so that the insurance will approve it.  I know it's hard to put out of your mind.  This is the hardest part... the waiting.  I hope that this will all soon be behind you and that it is benign.  You are the right age for a fibroadenoma,  I had one removed 3 months after my daughter was born a long time ago and it seems like a distant memory now, I even have to look when I have a mammogram to see which side the tiny scar is on so I can tell them.  Try to rest, and please try not to think about it in the middle of the night. Things seem worse then.  You are in my thoughts.
Posts.Title: Terrified I have Pregnancy Associated Breast Cancer inyoureyes inyoureyes

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 05:17AM - edited Jul 25, 2011 05:19AM by bedo rjbaby69 I was where you are 1 month ago.  My tumor was about your size.  I have IDC.  I coped by turning off my phone and not talking to anyone except the minimun for 2 weeks, but that's the was I cope.  I felt like screaming at cashiers who told me to "Have a nice day! :)   )  I felt like telling them, well, that's not going to happen, I have breast cancer.  I had a lumpectomy and will have radiation which is very doable I hear.  There are several stage 1V sisters  who are living, working and are NED (No evidence of disease)  Try to stick with where you are on the board or you make overwhelm yourself.  My daughter and sister were a great help when I finally let them help until my daughter said something very rude to me and I told her, " I'm still your Mom, don't ever speak to me like that again, I'm older than you I'm smarter and wiser than you , and it's not up to you to completely support me, I can do it.  It helped us both.  The best thing I did, after 2 weeks was to go down to the garden. Nature really made me feel better and I didn't think about cancer for hours.  I will be thinking of you today and please let us now your results. PS, when you just need a distraction the game section is fun.  I farm at farmville has gone to seed. PS, I was convinced it had spread to my leg..  Was shin splints.
Posts.Title: Need to Join - Got My Results rjbaby69 rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 07:37PM - edited Jul 25, 2011 07:54PM by bedo If you are estrogen and progesterone rececptor + and HER 2 neg with negative node s and clear margins, You have my exact findings.  My tumor was 1.6. the tumor board discussed it at Women and Infants in Providence and a lumpectomy was recommended.  with radiation.  Mastectomey was not discussed as an option  it was felt that it woud not help .I also asked for an oncotype test which is a test that looks at several characteristics of the tumor and tells how much additional benefit you would recieve from chemo, although it was not recommended to me.  My Mom and Dad died of cancer before I was 26 and I wanted to do all. I could. for my daughter I was told there would be a 7%-10% chance of  DISTANT mets in 10 years. with hormone suppression. I asked what if that happens? He said, we'll deal with it and you'll get more years.  You have to take into account your menopausal status.  Ask him for hard facts, yours may not be the same as mine re receptors, age, but the numbers helped me understand.  Also, some people are more comfortable with 7% others want it lower (I don't know if this would be lower if I had had a mastectomy) Grade 1 is Whoopee!  What a wimp of a cancer!  Not to down play it. Go with your gut if you will always be second guessing yourself go more agressive.  Discuss it with your family and you don't have to make a decision tomorrow.  There may be options for having family members drive you?  I was "fortunate" enough to be laid off with my whole department the week before the news so I had all the time in the world to think about it until my insurance runs out then I will do something.  So there are many 'good things'  support of farmily, trust in your surgeon, grade1 options, size 2 (cm) mine was actually 1.6 after surgery.  The surgeon made an incision very side of my breast about an inch and one around the nipple that will fade so that it won't show.  She said I could still wear low cut tops.  (As if I care, no one but senile old men what to look at these babies)  So good luck there. and keep us posted.  There are protocols out there for different types of breast cancer regarding size etc,  you could look up Mayo's or ACC or yours.  Someone help me out here!  I can't find it.  ! You could check with dlb823 she is very knowlegable  as are a lot of people. She also explained why they only took 2 nodes instead of a whole bunch, it's the new thinking. I'm sure she wouldn't mind if you pm'd her. So yippee, less chance of lymphadema

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 12:06PM - edited Dec 22, 2011 12:23PM by bedo DM13, My diagnosis was similair to yours, I believe.  I had a low oncotype score and I did not recieve chemo  I'm sorry you have to go through this.  I would get a second opinion and an oncotype test before I made any decision about chemo.  It's your body, not the doctor's.  I wish you the best of luck and am sorry you are here, but the women will help you, as they helped me.  The beginning is the worst part.  Once you have your plan in order and are confident about it, you will feel better, and feel as though you are taking steps to help fight the cancer.

Posts.Title: SEX - Very Raw Post cancerkicker Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 03:05PM - edited Feb 19, 2012 03:38PM by bedo Mirena has a form of progesterone in it, so yes you should have it removed, especially if you are PR+.  It shouldn't hurt too much coming out, but it depends on how sensitive you are.  Some people take an NSAID 30-45 minutes before removal and some take nothing. It is quick. It doesn't hurt as much as it did going in. You could ask for a paracervical block (numbing the cervix with lidocaine) but it is very unlikely that you would need it.and that would only be if there were difficulty. Very unlikely. Chances are, you'll be fine.  As far as having it out after chemotherapy, your provider might want to wait until your counts come up so that "disturbing things" doesn't cause an infection.  Mine fell out and I didn't know it!  Im not sure why he would check your hormones if you are post-menopausal.  Good luck fredntan! PS, just my thoughts!  Discuss it with your Gyno.  :)

Its been 6 months since diagnosis and I've done lumpectomy and rads with 6 month follow up and want to put it out of my mind. There is a bigger health issue *looming.* I think that with my diagnosis, this will probably not affect my survival time.. Maybe, maybe not the other one will, I just want to forget about all of it and live out the next 10, 20, 30 years without worry.  Am I crazy?  Or in denial.  I will keep my follow ups, but plan to move forward and forget about it unless a symptom comes up. . I am sorry if this offends anyone. I am wishing the best of continuing health to all my stage 1 sisters.

Posts.Title: Anyone else having irritability and anger issues? jennyboog Stacie

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 12:55PM - edited Dec 11, 2011 03:29PM by bedo Joan I am sorry you're going through all that.  I took 6 months off from work, not so much because of the physical recovery from surgery and radiation (I also had another sugery for another issue) but for other factors, and my doctor suggested it. Most important was fatigue from radiation and healing.  Also important was the  fact that I couldn't concentrate and felt my IQ had dropped 20 points.  Also, I was very emotional.  Going back into my profession would have hurt my reputation and possibly hurt others.  I am looking for a job now (I was diagnosed 2 weeks before our office closed 5 1/2 monhts ago) but still slept 12 hours last night. My mind is clear again but I anticipate mainly sleeping on my off hours and would prefer a 32 hour a week job. RI has 24 week short term disability. There were other issues going on with me, but there are 6 states that have it for people who live and work in them, if anyone needs to look into it.   So hang in there ladies,  things will get better. It's good to get out.  Treat yourself.  Summer will return.

I told the community garden manager because I couldn't take care of my plot. I told my violin teacher because she wanted to know why I wasn't in the group for awhile and I trust her.  I basically told people who I trusted to keep my medical issues (HIPPA quiet)  I needed some "cancer free zones" so I didn't tell friends who lived far away.  It was kind of wait and see.

Posts.Content: bedo wrote: I was diagnosed last July, lost my job 2 weeks before fell down the stairs after lumpectomy and had to have second surgery to repair a bone in my face and then rads. and had to move into a studio cabin.  At first I was depressed and lay around for a week, then I was just annoyed at everything.  Yesterday it hit me. It was BC. This may be a little dumb, but I was thinking, oh, it's just like that fibroadenoma you had taken out when you were 20.  I had a mini anxiety attack, which I never have. But maybe it is similair in prognosis since everything looks good?  I don't even know what I'm asking.  Has anyone else felt like this? Do I really have to be freaked out?  The Dr. said I will live for a long, long time. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I think I may be a little slow on the uptake bedo Susie123

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2011 10:51PM - edited Nov 5, 2011 11:01PM by bedo I think your friend should understand that this 51% increase is a Relative Risk.  In other words comparing the risk of someone who does a certain thing to someone who doesn't.  So if your   risk of breast cancer is 10% and you have a relative risk of 10% your risk goes to 11%  (10+ 10% 0f 10 which is 1)  The study does not mean that with higher intake, you have a 50% risk of breast cancer.  I think that special K  and Beacon explained it well. I'm sure that your friend meant well, but I would probably have had a snarky remark like " it IS really hard to understand statistics and breast cancer is so complex and individualized that that I think I will rely on my MO's opinion about this.but thank you for your concern and your friendship.".
Posts.Title: alcohol and bc risk hdangelbaby CameoBarbie

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2011 10:54AM - edited Nov 6, 2011 11:24AM by bedo SoulSista The study was for developing cancer in those who did not have it.  Special K went to a conference where they said that the risk of more than 5 drinks a week increased your relative risk  of recurrence by 34% , It probably goes up the more you drink over this, so the recommendation is 2-5 drinks a week. So the equation would be (risk of recurrence X 0.34) +(risk of recurrence).  There are 2 types of recurrence, distant and local but most docs seems to focus mainly on the distant.,  Also, the study for original cancers seems to show increasing alcohol effects the risk of Est + BC.more than other types. .That's my best answer, so I guess the best is less is better, but it's a personal choice. SpecialK Did they mention at the conference whether this included both kinds of recurrence? Thanks!
Posts.Title: alcohol and bc risk hdangelbaby CameoBarbie
